message: Most certainly explaining what I'm looking for very poorly
Redis is the bees knees, we use it all over the place on Convore
@jsoncorwin Why don't you want to store that in the db?
Too slow?
I'm not sure I understand the question, and I'm almost certain you're pursuing a lost ause
I'm interested in creating a global variable of sorts (sort of like what's stored in request.session, but cross session) without having to store data in the DB - is there anything like this?
Or do you want to store the data in-process?
in process is a bad idea
@alex I agree, I was just trying to get to the root of the question.
I'd probably reach for Redis for that task, TBH
I think Redis is ideal
didn't know if that was a poor approach though
i suppose that's what models are for - making table creation easy =p
That's the thing about Redis though, once you install it, you find all kinds of awesome ways to use it :) But I agree, doesn't seem absolutely necessary for this.
Maybe you want a memcached session backend?

say for each session I want to display a letter in the alphabet - a -> z, but I want to make sure each session can reserve a unique character for say 5mins, without any other session being assigned that letter
@jsoncorwin So it seems like you're still going to want to use some sort of place to store the data of which session has which letter
@ericflo redis isn't already there, and I wouldn't install it just for this! I do like the thought though
your opinion matters...i'll put you in that category
because there's no guarntee all requests hit the same process
n-teir and all
does that alphabet example help any?
i was just wondering if there was some better way that was implemented than DB
@jsoncorwin Do you have Redis installed already though? It might not be worth the extra operational overhead
lol
nah, it won't be overly slow, i just wasn't sure it was worth dealing with storing in DB, if there was a better way
i guess i could just use a simple table with a data column and an expiry column
i'll settle for that, as the 'django lords' of this topic say it should work ok =p
@ericflo - i'm always looking for a good excuse to tinker with new stuff....hopefully soon I'll get to install Redis!
Don't count me in that category
Maybe go with your caching backend. It's obvioulsy not reliably persistent - but might work for your example above.
I second @ericflo on that, Redis is amazingly versatile. We use it for both semi-temporary storage and as a message queue all over ep.io.

Nobody else has mentioned it, and it isn't really the 'right' way to do this, but you could just do it with the filesystem, I suppose.  Create a file named 'a', and if it exists, don't issue it again.  Periodically, check the 'created_on' attribute of the file, and if it's older than 5 minutes, you could remove it.
@andrewgodwin ins'nt that an issue given you'd want different eviction strategies?
@alex We eventually plan to run multiple instances of it, but at the moment, it's fast enough on a single box that isn't an issue.
Sounds like what you want is filesystem session storage, and then keep a cookie on the frontend of their session key
@andrewgodwin That's exactly our experience too, we're using it for different purposes, but it's so fast that one instance is fast enough for us for now.
@ericflo Given how good antirez is at this stuff, I half expect that when redis-cluster appears I'll be able to literally shove more hardware at it to make it scale.
Distributed systems are a whole different ballgame
@andrewgodwin I'm not quite as sure about that as you are.
some aspects of redis are really not ammeanable to trivial clustering/distribution

The design antirez showed in the slides from the UK meetup seemed solid, but I can't say I'll be comfortable running it in production for a very long time. Even basic Postgres replication makes me nervous still.

Well, I only said "half expect". Most of our stuff is built with eventual consistency in mind, so we can take a little worsening of the performance, but then again it's also built so it can be split into about 5 different redis servers. I suspect we may just throw more powerful hardware at the problem.
